  • (a): Sandt; GS algoritmen ikke stopper i løbet af de første \(4\) iterationer \(\implies\) vektorer \(a_1,\dots,a_4\) er lin. uafhængige \(\implies\) vektorer \(a_2,\dots,a_4\) er lin. uafhængige.
  • (d): Sandt; \(a_4=0\) \(\implies\) vektorer \(a_1,\dots,a_4\) er lin. afhængige \(\implies\) GS stopper allerede i iteration \(4\), ikke iteration \(5\)

contents.name: K04: Linear equations.  Gaussian elimination
contents.summary:
When: 20.02.2024, 12:30. This is a self-study with help.
Literature: [VMLS], Chapter 8 + slides. You may find a much more detailed explanation of row reduction with examples in Sections 1.1-1.2 of [Lay]="Linear Algebra and Its Applications" by Lay, Lay, McDonald (attached). Note: I only discuss the (non-unique) echelon form in my slides, after which we run a backward substitution algorithm, whereas Lay also talks about the reduced echelon form. Basically we do not explicitly perform "Step 5" of the reduction algorithm on p. 17 in Lay's book.

Exercises:

  • [VMLS]: 8.1, 8.3, 8.4, 8.6, 8.8, 8.9, 8.14, 8.16
  • [Lay]: 1.1.1, 1.1.6. Run backward substitution: 1.1.7, 1.1.9. Determine consistency: 1.1.15, 1.1.17. Find all solutions to the system: 1.2.7, 1.2.9, 1.2.11, 1.2.13. Existence/uniqueness: 1.2.15, 1.2.19

contents.name: K09: Introduction, terminology, standard form
contents.summary:
When: 18.03.2024, 10:15. Lecture followed up by exercises.
Literature: [AEP]: sections 7.1-7.3, 8.1-8.2.1

Exercises (most are from chapter9_exercises.pdf, see below). I recommend solving the practice problems, and at least a couple of exercises from each category besides "modelling". If you have time, please also look at the modelling exercises.

  • Solve the practice problems 1-4 on p.532
  • Solve graphically: exercises 9.2.7-9.2.10. I recommend trying to solve both the minimization and the maximization problem for each exercise.
  • Rewrite to standard form: [AEP] 8.4. Rewrite to standard, not canonical form: exercises 9.2.3-9.2.6. Randomize each problem by: randomly selecting minimize/maximize; then for each constraint randomly select from \(=\), \(\leq\), and \(\geq\); finally for each of the variables randomly select, whether it should be \(\geq 0\), \(\leq 0\), or "free"/no sign restrictied.
  • Modelling: exercises 9.2.1-9.2.2, 9.2.15.

contents.name: K10: Duality in linear optimization
contents.summary:
When: 22.03.2024, 12:30. This is a self-study with help.
Literature: [AEP], sections 7.4-7.5, sections 10.2-10.3 (up and including Theorem 10.6 w/o proof, pp 243-248)

Exercises (from chapter9_exercises.pdf). I recommend solving at least a couple of exercises in each category. If you have time remaining, solve a few more exercises from the previous session.

  • Rewrite to standard, not canonical form, and formulate the dual problem: exercises 9.2.3-9.2.6.
  • For each dual problem you stated in the standard form in the previous point, solve it graphically.
  • Using the optimal dual solutions for the problems in the previous point, find the corresponding primal optimal solutions. Use complementarity conditions.

pages.name: Purpose, content and evaluation
pages.content:
Module title (ENG/DK) and ECTS credits Probability Theory and Linear Algebra /Sandsynlighedsteori og lineær algebra (SLIAL) 5 ECTS
Module description Link:https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/22BMATSLIAL?lang=da-DK
Module coordinator Anton Evgrafov anev@math.aau.dk
Type and language Course, in English and Danish
Objectives The objective of this course is to expose the students to the fundamental linear algebraic and probabilistic/combinatorial concepts, such as:
  • Matrix and vector operations
  • Linear transformations and their connection to matrices
  • Invertible matrices/linear transformations, solution of linear algebraic systems
  • Orthogonality and least squares problems
  • Linear optimization
  • Discrete probability spaces and combinatorics
  • Markov chains, stationary distributions, and connections to linear algebra
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters See above
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 150 hours
Participants AAL-SW2, DAT2
Preprequisites for participation
Module activities (course sessions etc.) The course consists of four blocks.  Each block begins with a lecture followed by an exercise session.  Most other sessions in each block are "self-studies with help", where the students study the material independently (video lecture, textbook) while the teachers/assistants are available for help/answering questions.  Each block also contains a non-scheduled "self-study without help", where the students study the course material (video lecture, textbook, exercises) on their own.  Each block is concluded with a workshop/"mini-project".  
Examination Oral examination, 15 min/student including the grading.  The short presentation of a randomly selected workshop forms the basis for the final oral exam (~5 min).  The presentation is followed up by additional questions within the course's syllabus (~5 min). You may prepare ~5 slides/workshop and either print them out or show the screen when you present at the exam.

pages.name: Literature
pages.content:
There are three textbooks that we are going to use.

  • [VMLS]: Introduction to Applied Linear Algebra: Vectors, Matrices, and Least Squares by S. Boyd and L. Vandenberghe. Available for download here. Covers most of the linear algebra part of the course. This is our main textbook.
  • [Rosen]: Discrete Mathematics and Its Applications by K. Rosen. You have used this book in your DTG course. Here it is at FACTUM books. We will only use Chapter 7 in connection with discrete probability theory.
  • [AEP]: An Introduction to Continuous Optimization: Foundations and Fundamental Algorithms by Andreasson, Evgrafov, and Patriksson. Relevant chapters will be available on moodle.

courses.fullname: Algorithms and Data structures (ALG) (DAT2, AAL-SW2, DVML2)

contents.name: About the course
contents.summary:
(This course is taught in English)

Teacher: Giovanni Bacci

Teaching Assistants: Mads Corfixen, Claes Berg Mortensen, Victor Doré Hansen.

Study Secretary: Sidsel G. M. Overgaard

Description
An algorithm is a well-defined procedure to solve a specific problem. The study of algorithms is a key area of computer science that is essential for the development of correct and efficient software in any programming language. The course provides an introduction to the study of algorithms and data structures with a special focus on their design and analysis.

Textbook: the student can choose one of the following textbooks

  • Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein - Introduction to Algorithms, 4th edition. The MIT Press
  • Thomas H. Cormen, Charles E. Leiserson, Ronald L. Rivest, and Clifford Stein - Introduction to Algorithms, 3rd edition. The MIT Press

The course is 5 ECTS (~137,5 hrs) and is divided into 14 sessions: 12 regular sessions and 2 exam simulations

The exam will be in written form with external censors. Grades will be given according to the 7-points grading scale.

contents.name: Preliminary Notes
contents.summary:
To refresh your ability in performing mathematical proofs, I prepared a brief note on proof techniques with an emphasis on mathematical induction. Mathematical induction will be a useful tool in the course both to perform run-time analysis and to prove the correctness of algorithms.  

Please, read the notes and try to solve the exercises therein by yourself.

contents.name: Self-study Session 1 [20 March 2024]
contents.summary:
Part 1 (8:15 -- 10:00) 
  • the exercise sheet will be made available from 8:15
  • solve as many exercises as you can from the exercise sheet
  • write down your solutions as if this was a real-exam (i.e., strive for precision and clarity in your arguments)
  • work alone (you can look at the book or your notes, but you cannot get help from your peers or the TAs)
  • If some questions are not clear, contact Giovanni Bacci in private chat in MS Teams from 8:30 to 10:00
Part 2 (10:00 -- 12:00) 
  • discuss your solutions within your group in your group room
  • complete the exercises you did not solve on your own
  • the solution will be posted around 11:00. Use the last hour to discuss discrepancies between your solution and mine.
  • ask feedback to the TAs as a normal exercise session using the Digital TrashCan.
Pedagogical Remarks: 

  • the exercises are taken from old exams or they are slight adaptations. 
  • nevertheless, the exercise sheet does not represent an actual exam sheet
  • working individually during the first 2 hrs is meant to reproduce the conditions that you will find during the exam
  • exploit this opportunity to self-assess your preparation

pages.name: Purpose, content and evaluation
pages.content:
Module title and ECTS credits Algorithms and Data Structures /Algoritmer og datastrukturer (ALG), 5 ECTS
Module description Link: https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/DSNDATFB211?lang=da-DK
Module coordinator Giovanni Bacci (giovbacci@cs.aau.dk)
Type and language Course and in English
Objectives This course has the aim to teach the main principles of algorithm design. Through a number of examples, the course will try to convey both the general spirit of thinking about the algorithms and a number of commonly used techniques for algorithm design. We will see how these techniques can be used to solve different problems. The important part of the course will deal with the analysis of algorithms, where we will look at the ways to reason about the efficiency and correctness of algorithms. Finally, the course will present a small toolbox of commonly used algorithms and data structures. These algorithms can be considered to be the "classics" of computer science. In the course, we will spend plenty of time with each of these algorithms, favoring the quality of understanding to the quantity of algorithms covered
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 150 hours
Participants DAT2, AAL-SW2, DVML2
Prerequisites for participation
  • Understanding of basic control structures of imperative programming languages (i.e., if-then-else, for loop, while loop, variable assignment)
  • knowledge of basic arithmetic and properties of functions such as logarithms, polynomials, max, min, etc.
  • understanding of basic proof principles. In particular, induction.
Module activities (course sessions etc.) The course consists of 12 lectures followed by exercise sessions + 2 exam simulations 
Examination Written or oral examination - Please note: FINAL examination form (and aid if any) will be posted on the course page

pages.name: Exam Guidelines & Allowed aids
pages.content:
Guidelines for the exam:

  • Do not have contact with other students during the examination.
  • In the answer, it is sufficient to state the assignment number and your solution. You do not have to repeat the assignment text
  • CLRS-3 refers to the textbook T.H. Cormen, Ch. E. Leiserson, R. L. Rivest, C. Stein, Introduction to Algorithms (3rd edition). You can reference existing pseudo-code or theoretical results from the textbook.
  • CLRS-4 refers to the textbook T.H. Cormen, Ch. E. Leiserson, R. L. Rivest, C. Stein, Introduction to Algorithms (4rd edition). You can reference existing pseudo-code or theoretical results from the textbook.
  • It is important that your solutions are presented in a readable form.
  • The exam questions will be a mixture of arithmetic exercises, comprehension tasks, multiple-choice, and design and analysis of algorithms for solving simple computational problems.
  • If you believe that the assignment wording is ambiguous or erroneous, then write down what additional assumption you are using giving reasons for your answer.
  • The hand-in must be a single file in pdf format. Any additional file won't be considered for evaluation.
  • Make sure that the pdf is readable and contains all your solutions before you hand it in.
Aids allowed:

  • You can use your laptop provided that you run ITX Flex (digital exam guard) during the exam.
  • The CLRS book (electronic or paper version)
  • Use of the INTERNET is NOT allowed, except for accessing lectures’ slides, and exercise/old exams solutions published on the course's Moodle page. Access to video lectures is NOT permitted during the exam.  
  • Exercise solutions or notes that you have created yourself, i.e., made entirely yourself or as an active participant in the group work (electronic or paper version).   
  • Common IT tools like PDF reader, internet browser (only to access the course's Moodle page), and calculator. 
  • You can write code during the exam and execute it using an IDE. But you are not allowed to load and/or execute any code or script that was produced prior to the exam. This also includes external and standard libraries.
  • Remark: the term "calculator" is interpreted in the broad sense. You can use Maple, Wordmat, Mathematica, and Geogebra as long as you do not load code/documents that were produced prior to the exam. This also includes external and standard libraries.

pages.name: FAQ
pages.content:
Q1: What am I allowed to use for the exam?

A1: look at the Exam Guidelines & Allowed aids

Q2: How many points to pass the exam?

A2: your exam will be graded according to the 7-scale grading system. The point system you can see on the side of each exercise has to be considered as an indication of the relative (expected) difficulty of each question within the exam sheet. During the grading phase, points will be used only to get an indicative overview of how the whole class performed in each question. There is no fixed conversion from points to grades. 

Q3: What happens if I mark some answers wrong in a multiple-choice question?

A3: see Q4 

Q4: What happens if my answer to an exam question is partially correct on not complete?

A4: we will evaluate to what extent your answer demonstrates knowledge/skills related to the learning goals listed in the study regulation. This means that even if the answer is not complete, there is a good chance that the part that has been completed will give some indication of the level of fulfillment of the subject's objectives covered by the specific question.

Q5: Do I have to justify my answers in the multiple-choice questions?

A5: you have to justify your answer only if the exam question explicitly asks you to do so.

pages.name: Purpose, content and evaluation
pages.content:
Module title (ENG/DK) and ECTS credits Internetworking and Web-programming / Internetværk og web-programmering (IWP), 5 ECTS
Module description Link: https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/DSNDATFB212?lang=da-DK
Module coordinator Michele Albano (mialb@cs.aau.dk), Brian Nielsen (bnielsen@cs.aau.dk)
Type and language Course and in English/Dansk
Objectives This course has the aim to give an understand how applications communicate over the the Internet, how the Internet is structured, understand the workings of common Internet Protocols (in particular TCP and UDP), security challenges, and give basic skills in developing web-based applications. 
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters The course is related to the programming course at 1st semester, programming courses at later semesters, computer architecture & operating systems (4th semester), distributed systems (7th semester), and IoT (for BAIT)
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 150 hours
Participants DAT2, AAL-SW2, BaIT6T
Preprequisites for participation Programming experience from 1st semester.
Module activities (course sessions etc.) The course consists of lecture/exercise sessions
Examination Written or oral examination - Please note: FINAL examination form and aids (if any) will be posted on the course page

pages.name: Decription of the course (DK)
pages.content:
Computer netværk, og især Internettet spiller i dag en enorm rolle i den måde som vi anvender computere på, og i den måde vi programmerer større applikationer. Tænk på Intranet til deling af fælles ressourcer som printere, netværksdrev, og interne dokumenter. Tænk på Internet til sociale medier, WWW, fil-deling, chat, video-konference, streaming og gaming, Internet-of-things og cyber-physical systems, der kobler den fysiske verden til nettet. Personlige netværk til dit telefon, smart-watch, høretelefoner hører også med. Endvidere kører moderne programmer (applikationer) ofte "over nettet". De er delt op i en front-end på brugerens enhed og en back-end, der kører på en server eller i en sky (som software-as-a service).  Alternativt, anvender programmer ofte eksisterende services som komponenter, og anvender disse via Web-API som del af programmet.  Derfor bør en professionel datalog eller software ingeniør have et fundamentalt kendskab til hvordan netværk er opbygget, virkemåde, og hvordan de kan programmeres. 

Kurset følger en top-down tilgang, hvor vi starter med programmering af applikationer, både front-end (klient) og back-end (server) delen. Specifikt får du i IWP en grundlæggende introduktion til ”front-end triaden” JavaScript, HTML5, (i begrænset omfang) CSS , og back-end systemet Node.js, der også muliggør programmering af denne del vha. JavaScript. Kurset introducerer de dele af JavaScript, der er nødvendige for kurset, men nedtoner mange feature, ligesom funktions- og objekt-orienteret programmering kommer i andre kurser senere i uddannelsen. Klient og server delene bindes sammen med kommunikation ved brug af http protokollen. Kurset viser hvordan simple dynamiske web-sites og web-apps kan programmeres.  

Herefter tager vi en kort, mere klassisk introduktion til de underliggende netværkslag og almindelige Internet protokoller: Applikationslags-protokoller, som applikationer typisk benytter sig af. Dernæst transportlags-protokoller (som handler om at få data helt og korrekt og effektivt frem til modtageren).  Transportlaget kan programmers direkte vha. "Sockets" abstraktionen.  Da kurset bredt orienteret mod software ingeniører og dataloger fokuserer vi på de øverste lag i stakken (til og med transport laget) og mindre på de underliggende netværks- og link-laget.

Udover at give nyttig viden og kompetencer i sig selv, illustrerer kurset også generelt hvordan komplekse systemer (som Internettet) kan bygges ved at opdele dem i lag med stigende grad af "abstraktion", men også begrænsninger ved disse, og at man til tider skal kende til de underliggende teknologier. Af tilsvarende generel viden er begrebet "protokoller", der definerer måden hvorpå to eller flere del-systemer skal kommunikerer for at virke korrekt.  Endeligt er faget en del af distribuerede systemer, som du kan komme til at stifte yderligere bekendtskab med senere i uddannelsen.

Eksamen er en 4-timers skriftlig prøve, og vil bestå af en teori-del (ca. 70%) og en hands-on del (ca 30%). Teori-delen er en blanding af multiple-choice og traditionelle opgaver, der skal checke forståelsen af pensum. Hands-on delen vil typisk være en mindre programmeringsøvelse. Eksamen i F24 forventes gennemført som en moodle quizz. 

Tidsforbrug Vi forventer at tidsforbruget vil være nogenlunde jævn gennem semesteret med normalt 1 lektion om ugen. Fordelingen af aktivitet ser sådan ud:

  • 5 ECTS =def 5 * 30 timer = 150 timer studieaktivitet
  • 12 lektioner á 2 timer   = 24 timer
  • 12 øvelsesgange á 2 timer +
    1 øvelsesgang á 4 timer  = 28 timer
  • 4 timers læsning til hver lektion ~= 48 timer
  • Resterende øvelser hjemme  = 20 timer
  • Eksamens-repetition     = 30 timer
  • I alt 150 timer i alt

--Michele&Brian

pages.name: Lecture Material
pages.intro: Specific material to read for this lecture.
pages.content:
This is the mandatory reading material for this lecture:

Reading guide:

These chapters introduce the basic programming concepts in JavaScript (JS): Types, Values, Expressions, Variables, Statements. There are quite many pages, but most concepts should be familiar from your experience with the C-language. Pay particular attention to how values and types works in JS; string processing plays an important role in web-programming, so pay attention to the JS string processing features. If you are struggling with programming, take extra time to get acquainted with the concepts. 

[DF] Chapters 1-5 (11+6+29+13+15=74 pages): SKIP the sections mentioned below

  • Chapter 1: but skip 1.4 for now

  • Chapter 3: but skip
    • 3.2.5, BigInt: 
    • 3.6, Symbols: 2
    • 3.2.10 VAR: 1
    • 3.10.3 Destructuring assignment: 4
  • Ch4: Expressions, but SKIP
    • 4.4.1 Conditional property access 2
    • 4.5.1 Conditional invoke 1 
    • 4.7 (operators and precedense. Serves as Reference manual) 4
    • 4.9.2 comparison 2
    • 4.9.3 in operator 4.9.4 instanceOf 1 4.10 logical expr 3
    • 4.12 EVAL 4 
    • 4.13 Other 5 statements
  • Chapter 5, but SKIP
    • “For of” with MAP, “async for/await”,p 110
    • 5.4.5 for /in 2
    • 5.5, but do read 5.5.4  about "return", and note the existence of "break" and "continue"; 8
    • 5.6, but read 5.6.3 “strict mode“. 2
    • 5.7.3, 5.7.4: 1 5.8  :1

Supplementary material:

There are many books that focus on the Javascript language. Not all are equally good, even if they are commercial (and even pricey). 

  •  Marijn Haverbeke: Eloquent JavaScript. 3rd edition (2018). A good free introduction to JS programming, but also become fairly convoluted.  
  • Axel Rauschmayer has written a number of  useful (partly free or DRM-less) books on JavaScript, see the page Exploring JS: JavaScript books for programmers, including: 

  • JavaScript for impatient programmers (ES1–ES2019), Introductory 
  • Deep JavaScript: Theory and techniques (ES1–ES2019), Advanced
  • Speaking JavaScript (ES1–ES5), Introductory, but not fully updated with newest language features.

  • [MDN] Also has numerous guides for JavaScript
  • Javascript.info is another usefull web-based guide for JavaScript and front-end development
  • https://jstherightway.org/ numerous other Javascript related guides. 
  • Algorithms in JavaScript An AUB online Book using JavaScript to exemplify how to write algorithms.
  • Introduction to new JavaScript versions. Another AUB online book.

pages.content:
Part 1: Basic tool installation and usage:

  1. Install the basic developer tools:
  2. Chrome Browser

console.log("Hej med dig!");
  1. Next declare a variable a with value 40 and a constant b with value 2, and a variable c that equals the sum of a and b. Recall the "let" and "const" syntax from the lecture!

     

  2. Redo exercise 5+6 using the node interpreter.


  3. Loading and running files. The following exercises is most conveniently done using a proper code editor. You may use Emacs, or as recommended in this course the Visual Studio Code editor. You can use the following files as a starting point. Unzip them into a suitable location.  
    -To run in a browser, open the "demo.html" file (than in turn will load your script). Inspect the browsers javascript console.
    -To run in node.js, open a command line, change directory to the location inside the downloaded archive. Then type "node demo,js"
    -You may also run it in node from within VSCode (assume that you open the included workspace file in VSCode). Here there are two options, either run it in the built-in terminal, or better using the built-in DEBUGGER  by pressing F5. The result is shown below. If the debug-console sub-window does not appear, you may need to enable it in the "View" menu.

      

Part 2: Some JavaScript Programming assignments


  1. [MH] p38 Triangle (Using iteration)
  2. [MH] p38. Chessboard
  3. Here is a declaration of a JS function "renderPage" that accepts 3 strings (title,heading,demoString) as argument:
 function renderPage(title,heading,demoString) { }
  • Complete its body such that it returns a string with this contents when called with 
     
    renderPage("Simpel IWP Demo", "IWP demo","JS Script er kørt")

    For the time being, you don't need to understand the contents of the string - just treat it as a black-box.
  • Try to use both string concatenation, and template literals. Using string concatenation, like C you use backslash \ to escape special characters like " and \n to produce newlines, and \ directly followed by newline just breaks the string to the next line. Note that template literals often are smarter for this style of use. 
  • Print the string to the console and copy&paste it into an editor (plain notepad will suffice), save it as "myfile.html". Load the file into a web-browser. This is a first taste of how scripts produce html;-).

4. Write a JS function that takes an array of strings as argument and computes (as return value) the average length of the strings. Ie. the following input it should compute (5+3+4)/3=4.


let strings=["Hejsa", "med", "dig!"];

pages.name: Lecture material
pages.content:
Lecture Material

This is the mandatory reading material for this lecture:

Reading guide:

These chapters introduce the basics of objects, arrays, and functions JS. Objects are basic building blocks in JS; they can serve as 'structs', but may also contain user defined data what operates on the contained data. In contrast to C, arrays in JS are dynamic and flexible, and a rich set of notations for creating them, and operations on them is offered. Functions plays a crucial role in JS and in web-programming. We will need to be able to define functions, and define functions that uses functions as parameters (and produces them as return values): PAY PARTICULAR ATTENTION TO FUNCTIONS!

[DF] Chapters 6,7,8 (14+11+ 16 pages = 41 pages): SKIP the sections mentioned below
  • Chapter 6 (Objects), skip sections
    • 6.4 deleting properties
    • 6.5 testing props 1
    • 6.10 Litt syntax, gett/setters 7
  • Chapter 7 (Arrays): skip sections
    • 7.1.2 spread op: 1 
    • 7.3 Sparse arrays 1
    • 7.7 multi-dim: 1
    • 7.8 Array metoder; read 7.8.1, skim the rest and use as reference and to lookup when needed (8) 
    • 7.9 Array-like 2
  • Chapter 8 (Functions Important!): Skip sections 
    • 8.3 (pp 5) , but read 8.3.1-8.3.2
    • 8.5 namespaces 1
    • 8.6 closures 6
    • 8.7 func props 4
    • 8.8 Higherorder functions, but read 8.8.1: 5

Supplementary material:

pages.name: Exercises
pages.content:
Part 1. Fun with Functions

In this exercise we will gradually use more and more aspects of JS functions on a simple example. 
let diceRoll=[1,6,6,2,3,4,6];

  1. Write a function get6s_v1 that takes an array of numbers (dice values 1..6) as parameter, and prints the indexes and corresponding values of the array where elements are 6s. E.g., 1:6, 2:6, 6:6 ..." excluding other elements. At this stage, just write a basic version, eg. without using functions as parameters
    Apply the function to the above array as argument.
  2. Write a helper function eg "is6(v)" that can test if the supplied parameter value v is a 6 
    Rewrite get6s_v1 to get6_v2 such that it uses the helper function to test if the index/value should be printed. 
    Apply the function to the above array.  
  3. Now create a get6s_v3 that rewrites get6_v2 to accept a dice array as first parameter, and a "compare" function as second parameter.
    Apply the function using the diceRoll and function "is6" as actual arguments
  4. Copy and rename the get6s_v3 function to findDices_v1(dice,compare). Call it with the same arguments as above using the diceRoll and function "is6"
    Then call it using a function expression (named or anonymous) at the call site, to pass a function that selects 1 dices. 
  5. Then call it using a lambda expression to pass a function that selects dices with values <= 3. 
  6. (advanced:)  what does the following statement produce? 
    diceRoll.filter(dice=>dice==6).reduce((sum,dice)=>sum+dice,0);

Part 2. Objects & Arrays

  1. Declare an object "msgBoard" that represents a message board that a set of clients can use to exchange messages.
    It should have a property for the  name of the message board, initialized to "IWP Chat", and another property (array) for storing the history of messages. 
    Add a function (method) to the object called "putMessage" that takes a string message as argument at stores it in the message array.
    Add a function (method) that prints the received messages to the console. I.e, the messageBoard could be used like:

    msgBoard.putMessage("Hej, dette er en test");
msgBoard.putMessage("Hej IWP");
    msgBoard.printMessages();

It should result in the following output
Messages History in board IWP Chat:
Hej, dette er en test
Hej IWP

  2. Add a function "register(f)" to the object that clients use to be notified when new messages arrives (a so-called call-back function): The register function takes a function f as argument, and stores the passed function in a different array "callBacks". f itself takes two parameters: the name of the message board, and the message. Then prints them to the console, possibly in an client specific manner (eg language).   
    Based on the putMessage method, add a similar one "sendAndNotify" that in addition to storing the message (eg using putMessage) also calls all registered call-back functions whenever a message arrives (supplying the registered function with the new message, and boardname.


    function briansHandler(boardName,message){
      console.log(`Brian! A message from ${boardName}: ${message}`);
      }
     msgBoard.register(briansHandler);
     msgBoard.register((board,message)=>console.log(`Board ${board} says to Michele: ${message}`));
     msgBoard.sendAndNotifyMessage("URGENT: Opgaveregning nu!")
    

It should result in the following output
Brian! A message from IWP Chat: URGENT: Opgaveregning nu!
Board IWP Chat says to Michele: URGENT: Opgaveregning nu!

  3. Make a constructor function  MessageBoard(name) that makes message boards.
Create a few message boards.   

 let board2= new MessageBoard("Opgave Regning"); 
 board2.putMessage("Hej, dette er en test");

Part 3. BMI Calculator - Console Edition

The following archive contains the (console version) of the the BMI Calculator. 

Uncompress to a suitable location,  and simply double click the bmi.code-workspace. (debugging console applications: 

Tilføj "console": "integratedTerminal" til launch.json, see https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/47860) )



There are two versions included in separate files: 
  • app-c.js is using very plain imperative style programming. 
  • app-js.js uses a some more js features (objects with methods, array functions, and constructor functions) 

However, I "forgot" to implement a couple of functions. 

  1. First take the app-c.js. Try to get an overview of the functions in the file (disregard those that renders html for the first time). But remark the importance of input validation  - this will also be important later.
    Implement the missing contents of the functions calcBMI and bmiLookup. 
  2. Then take a look at app-js.js. Remark the two constructor functions, and how some of the c-functions have been rewritten into member-functions. Locate the empty calcBMI and lookup functions and supply their contents. Consider using the array methods such as filter and indexOf.

Part 1: HTML Markup

  1. Warm up HTML exercises 
    1. https://www.w3schools.com/html/exercise.asp?filename=exercise_html_headings3

  2. BMI HTML help page
    1. Do semantic HTML markup of a simple BMI help page to be stored in the file "help.html".  After mark up, it (raw text supplied for your convenience) should display the page as shown below. You may use this bmi image. 
      In the places indicated in the screenshot below, it should include include links  to
      -https://iform.dk/vaegttab/hvad-betyder-dit-bmi-tal#BMI-ulemper,
      -https://denstoredanske.lex.dk/body_mass_index,
      -equation 1 and to alternative methods on the help page itself.   Does your HTML pass the validator at https://validator.w3.org/#validate_by_input ? (you can paste your html directly) 

      IT IS CRUCIAL THAT YOU DO SEMANTIC MARKUP AND CONSIDER USING THE RIGHT ELEMENTS THAT MATCH THE INTENTION OF EACH PORTION OF TEXT THE BEST AND SEPERATE LAYOUT AND STYLING AWAY FROM THE HTML. THE TASK IS NOT JUST TO MAKE SOME CODE THAT GRAPHICALLY LOOKS SIMILAR.





    2. This exercise extends the BMI console application from lecture 2. In the present version it renders a table in the output file  bmiStatus.html. Inspect the code that does the rendering. Locate the functions, and try to understand how they construct the strings containing the html page.

      Now your task is to extend the table with an additional column that contains the change in BMI between records. It may appear like the screenshot below:

      Also the page should include a relative link to the the help page that you just authored. Write a general helper function renderAnchor(text,url) that returns the text string for the anchor element;



Part 2: HTML Forms (VIGTIG)   

  1. Forms Warm up
    1. https://www.w3schools.com/html/exercise.asp?filename=exercise_html_forms2
    2. https://www.w3schools.com/html/exercise.asp?filename=exercise_html_form_elements2

  2. BMI registration form. 
    1. The lecture explained the HTML for setting up the BMI record configuration form. Extendnd that HTML form to enable age and gender to be submitted. The form should appear like the unstyled form illustrated below:



      (With simple styling the form could finally appear like the image below. DO NOT SPEND EXERCISE TIME ON DOING THIS STYLING: ONLY SHOWN FOR ILLUSTRATIVE PURPOSES!)


    2. In this exercise you are to inspect the data that is exchanged between a client and a server when the client submits a form using HTTP. 
      1. First, locate the browsers developer tools, and its network inspector. Since we don't have a server yet, we will use the a test server: httbin.org that simple sends back a json document with the data received from the client.  Change your form to point to the test server: 
        <form action="https://httpbin.org/post" method="post">
        Load the html page into the browser. You should now see the communication being listed, see illustration below.
      2. Inspect the exchanged header and body information in the request and response.
        What url is issued? What resource at the server is being accessed? what HTTP method?
        How is the form data sent to the server? What content-type?
        What is the content of the response? Does the request succeed?

        <form action="https://httpbin.org/get" method="get">

pages.name: Solutions
pages.content:
Read This First!

Are you sure you want to peek?

Consult a TA first to discuss the exercise and potential solution! Simply reading a proposed solution may not give you the deeper understanding that is expected, and will not help you in the thought process that you need to solve similar problems.  

BMI extensions, help page, and extended form are included in this archieve. 




  • HTTP:
    1. The requested url is: https://httpbin.org/post . I.e  protocol-scheme HTTPS, domain httpbin.org, and resource path "post". The http-method is POST. The fact that the resource name  "post" co-insides with the HTTP method is an artefact of the function of the server to act as a test site. Don't confuse the two. The resource could have (better) been named "post-test". On the other hand the HTTP methods is fixed by the HTTP protocol specification. 
    2. In a post request, the form parameters are transferred in the body. Its content type is : "application/x-www-form-urlencoded". the actual content is the string:  name=Mickey&height=180&weight=118&age=111&sex=indifferent .
    3. The response is a json (javascript serialized object notation) document: content-type "application/json"  (probably around 1352 bytes long as per the header field)
    4. The request was successful as per the status code "200".

    5. USING GET the URL is: https://httpbin.org/get?name=Mickey&height=180&weight=100&age=40&sex=indifferent  I.e  protocol-scheme HTTPS, domain httpbin.org, and resource path get?name=Mickey&height=180&weight=100&age=40&sex=indifferent. The http-method is GET. IE the form data is transferred as part of the URL in the query string. 
    6. The request has no content-type because the GET does not carry a body. 
    7. The response is a json document. 
    8. The reequest is successfull as per the status code "200"

pages.name: Exercises
pages.content:
Part 1: 

Remaining exercises from last lecture.

Part 2: "BMI Site" (dynamically server side generated HTML) .

(read through the the entire assignment first, to get an overview).

In this exercise session you will work with this sample implementation of the BMI tracker developed as a web-site style application, where the presentation html is produced by Javascript at a server. The structure is also described in the lecture Slides. When done, your implementation should appear somewhat like the screenshots below: 


  1. Download the archieve, unzip, open the workspace file in VSCode. Start the server, either from within VSCode, or using the command   "node node/app.js" in the unzipped directory (On linux you may instead need to use node ./node/app.js). Point your browser to "http://127.0.0.1:3000/" (or http://localhost:3000/). Record a bmi entry or two, and look at the stats.  
  2. Install the help.html file that you created last week:
    -put it in the proper directory. Which?
    -Also store the required image to the proper directory. Which? 
    Hint: The server is written such that it re-directs resource paths that it does not know of (where no JavaScript function is attached) to the file-system, assuming a file need to be served instead. Remember that the client has no direct access to the server-side application files! 
    -Try it out by viewing it in browser (accessed via the server, not filesystem). Which URL do you need to use?  
    -You may need to adjust your relative image paths in the html document (depends on how you exactly did the exercise).
    -Ensure that the image is also shown.  
  3. Try to get an overview of the app.js file 
    You do not  need to look at the file server.js and router.js: in a later lecture will explain how to program a simple web server in node.js and route requests to javaScript functions.

    Locate the major pieces: the set of functions called by the server/router module, how is input data validated, how is data recorded in the DB, how are the resulting HTML pages genereated?.
    Yes, reading somebody else's code takes effort! Consider how will you deliver your own code to others!
  4. Add links:
    • The front page (containing the forms) should contain a link to the help file.
    • Also, the page containing the output of recording a BMI entry should contain navigation links (i.e., in a NAV element): one to navigate "back" to the front page allowing the user to easily restart, one to the help page, and one giving direct access to the users statistics page. The same navigation links should appear at the record result page, so you may want a helper function to render that. 
    • You may want to use your  generic helper function that construct and return a string containing an anchor element, given the destination url and anchor text as parameters (last lecture).    
  5. Extended input data form.
    • Extend the record BMI  form to include the two additional inputs: age and sex. These may be used in a future version of the programme. 
      You need to validate the extra input fields at the server side to ensure that they satisfy the input constraints. See the constants in the top of the app.js file! 
      Hint: Locate the function that validate the BMI Record form. 
    • Add functionality to give men with a BMI of more than 30 a "Beware" indication after a new record has been submitted, see screenshot. 


  6. BMI Delta (Optional)
    • Extend the statistics form with a the changes of BMI (delta) functionality from the previous lecture.  
  7. Optional The present archive is based on the c-style version of the BMI-console application. If you prefer, re-write it to use the more js-style (as found in app-js.js in the BMI console assignment/solution.

Til denne denne lektion er det især træer og lister, I skal bide mærke i)


Reading material from [DF] 

The chapters mainly concerns how JavaScript is handled at the client (browser) side and some important client-side programming interfaces. However, remember, it is not the intention that you memorize every single function and event mentioned here. But it is important that you get the idea of registering event handler functions, the idea of representing HTML as a tree of objects, and that JavaScript can change this (and by implication the page shown to the user).

pages.name: Exercises
pages.content:
In this sessions you will work with aspects of a (non-BMI) html-based user interface for a beer evaluation system. It shows how to use javascript at browser clients to change the user-interface to make it more interactive, and possibly dynamically changed based on server side data. We will gradually build the functionality illustrated in the screenshots illustrated in the images below. (Next lecture will show how to use "fetch" to dynamically retrieve data from/send data to the server side. )   

Part 1: Using javaScript to perform basic interaction the the  DOM

1. Below you find the html for a (parts of a simple page for) entering the choice of beers. Add the javaScript to readout (print to console) the names  and statuses (whether they are checked or not) of the radio buttons. Your solution should work with a document containing further forms. It can be solved in several ways. 
    •   Hint 1: You need to locate the html-element to get a handle to its DOM object: Use either document.getElementById (thereby needing to add the necessary id attributes) or the document.querySelector/document.querySelectorAll to get a javaScript object references to the buttons.  Further hint: you can use the CSS attribute selector [] to select element that has a specific attribute set. e.g input[name="xxx"] to find input elements with name set to "xxx"; 
    •   Hint 2:  radio-button elements has a boolean property ".checked" that indicates whether it is checked or not; the name is available in its  .value property. 
   
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="da">
<head>
  <title>IWP Demo</title>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
</head>
<body>   
    <form id="beerForm">
    <fieldset> <legend> Vælg Øl Type: </legend>
        <input type="radio" name="gæringstype" value="ales" checked> Overgæret (Ale)       
        <input type="radio" name="gæringstype" value="lagers"> Undergæret (Lager)  
        <input type="radio" name="gæringstype" value="wilds" > Vildtgæret (Lambic)
        <input type="button" value="Start">
        </fieldset>
    </form>
    <script>    </script>    
</body>    
</html>
2. Use the DOM API to insert a h1 element with the text "Vælg en Øl-type" immediately before the form: Use document.createElement to create a new element and the appropriate (Section 15.3.5 in [DF]) append, prepend, before, after method(s).

3. Registering eventHandlers 
3a. Attach an event-handler function to the start button (using addEventListener). The function should print the status of the radio buttons to the console (you may want to wrap you solution to Q1 as a function 'listChecked' for this purpose). 
3b. Now do the same for each radio button, such that each button reacts to a click by logging the statuses (re-using your above function). 

Part 2: Some security concerns
4.  Make a spy functionality:
  • Whenever the user hovers the mouse over an element on the page, this should be caught by an event-handler function that extracts information about the target HTML element (its nodeName and innerHTML; both available via the "target" property of the event object transferred to the event handler function (e.g event.target.nodeName ) and logs it to the console. You can use the beer page, a page of your own, or the HTML from http://people.cs.aau.dk/~bnielsen/IWP/links.html. 
  • Optionally, It can be extended with a key-logger feature (listen for "keydown" events). 
  • (To be done in a future exercise, but all that remains for you to have made an effective spy script is to "smuggle" this script to the user, and use HTTP POST to send the logged entry using the fetch-api  to a web-server (node.js application) under your control, and you are effectively remotely observing what the user is interested (at least as indicated by the mouse position), or types (including passwords on the page)

Hint: you can attach the event handler for the "mouseover" event to an outer HTML element such as document.body (or even the global window object); In this case also print out the event's currentTarget property to show the difference to the "target" property. 

5. Add the following script element: <script src="http://people.cs.aau.dk/~bnielsen/IWP/test.js"></script> 
  Load your html containing that element into your browser. Discuss the possible security implications of this. What if such a script could be "fetch"ed and executed from a script attached to your document?

Part 3: Building UI based on server side data

6a. The objective of this exercise is to pretend that the following object has been received from a webserver and, based on this information, to  build 3 HTML select menu lists resp. for ales, lagers, wilds using the DOM functions.
Hint: Take it step by step:

    • First, you may need to get comfortable with the select menu by constructing it as static HTML. 
    • Then make a function that uses DOM to construct the same element.
    • Then develop a reusable function that takes an array of strings as argument (and an id attribute string for the menu) that returns the constructed HTML element. 
    • Insert the elements after the button. 

  let beerTypes={
  ales: ["Bitter", "Pale Ale", "Brown Ale", "Trappist", "Porter",  "Weizenbier"],
  lagers:["Pilsner", "Münchener", "Wiener", "Bock", "Porter"],
  wilds: ["Gueuze", "Faro", "Fruit"]
  };
6b. Next, only the menu that corresponds to the selected beer type should be shown (ie there is one drop at a time). Hint: replaceWith and event-handlers on the radio buttons! The same handler function can be registered on all three buttons, and the exact target can be detected e.g using event.target.value

  

6c. As a final step, the beerTypes object should be"fetch"'ed from a server (i.e. contents not declared as an array at client). You can use the BMI-site server from last for this purpose: Deposit your exercise.html file (containing the script that does fetch on in the directory for HTML files. Also add a file "beer.json" that contains 

{"ales":["Bitter","Pale Ale","Brown Ale","Trappist","Porter","Weizenbier"],"lagers":["Pilsner","Münchener","Wiener","Bock","Porter"],"wilds":["Gueuze","Faro","Fruit"]}

Your java script is to fetch it using the "idiom" fetch("/beers.json").then().then().catch(); See slides and textbook Section 15.11.1 p 519 

First, check that you receive the object by printing it to the console in the .then() after deserialisation of the json response. Then alter that call-back function to also present the fetched result to the gui (that will be the task of the call back function given to .then).  

(This exercise is to mimic the situation where javaScript objects are retrieved from a server, and displayed to the user; here in a fancy style where the GUI elements are also tailored. )

Part 4: Optional exercises

7. (OPTIONAL) You may further expand the system above by adding a menu for choosing different functionality of the beer app: Add a <nav> element with a button for each functionality. For each functionality add a section containing the HTML for each section. Only the currently selected section should be shown. The functionality can be changed by clicking the corresponding function button. Hint: you can control the visibility of an element through the properties display.style="none" or display.style="block".   If you like, you can change the color or style of each button to indicate which function is activated. Instead of a "button" you can also use a <div> FUNCTION </div> to act like a button (easier to style).; or use pictures as buttons. 

It could appear something like: 

     

8. Animation (OPTIONAL)

Try out this simple animation demo https://eloquentjavascript.net/14_dom.html#c_SCZYa8azNm (remark you can run the example directly on the page using the "burger" menu, see picture

Then to the "Cats hat": https://eloquentjavascript.net/14_dom.html#p_3jJ377egS/

pages.name: Exercises
pages.content:
1) [fetch] If you did not complete exercise 6c from lecture 5, do it now that we have more knowledge about the use of fetch().


2) [exceptions] According to an old kids' song ( see https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PB9Mr1k_3KQ ), little monkeys like to jump on beds. Develop a script to perform the validation of the number of little monkeys jumping on the bed, which must be a number x between 1 and 5. When the user inputs the number, you either output a message such as "... little monkeys are jumping on the bed" for x times, or you wait 2 seconds and then complain to the user. You can use the same <div> element for the message and for the complaint. Use exceptions (e.g.: "not a number", "too many monkeys", "at least one monkey please") for the validation. You can start from the following HTML code:


<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <title>IWP Validation Exercise</title>
  <meta charset="UTF-8">
<script>
function monkeysJump(event) {
  event.preventDefault()
  ...
}
</script>
</head>
<body>
    <form id="myForm" >
        How many little monkeys are jumping on the bed? <input type="text" id="monkeys" value="" >
    </form>
    <div id="message" style="white-space: pre;" />
<script>
document.getElementById("myForm").addEventListener("submit", monkeysJump);
</script>
</body> 

Questions:

- what is the meaning of "event.preventDefault()" in monkeysJump?

- why do I use style="white-space: pre;" in the message div?


3.a) [promise] Write a promise based code that allows a function that is executed on a mouse-click on a button. The function will:

     1. wait 2 seconds "then()" print (console.log) "Hej". After that, the program will

     2. wait for 2 seconds and "then()" print "IWP". After that, it will

     3. wait for 2 more seconds and "then()" print "I am done".

The hard part of the exercise is implementing promises that wait for the 2 seconds. Inspire yourself to slides 36-37 to see how to encapsulate other asynchronous mechanisms into promises.

When testing your solution, try also to click the button twice very fast.


3.b) [async / await] Change your solution to 3.a to use async functions and the await keyword.

Question: Is it possible to remove all "then()" usage? (Consider both return values and side effects)


4) [fetch] When a fetch fails. Write a function where you fetch a resource, and try to parse it as JSON data (or plain text). console.log() different error messages for the different issues you can have. 

  1. try to fetch a URL of a server that doesn't exist;   (http://ikkeensite.dk/), 
  2. try to access a json object that does not exist; for example, you can access your BMI App: http://127.0.0.1:3000/html/findesej.json
  3. try to interpret as JSON a content that is non-JSON. You could try to parse into JSON an HTML document. For example, you can access your BMI App that you developed on Lecture 4's big exercise session http://127.0.0.1:3000/html/exercisesDom1.html (or any name you gave to your html page when you solved the exercise)
  4. try to fetch a legal json resource from a different origin than your document: e.g.: http://people.cs.aau.dk/~bnielsen/IWP/scores.json
To solve all the sub-exercises together, you could develop a HTML page with 4 buttons, one for each outcome described above.  To handle the errors and show good information to the user, you may be inspired by the fetch error handling code on page [DF] 356/357 


Supplementary exercises:

5.a) [parallel fetch] Create a page with 100 images that are not loaded yet (for example, <div>s), and one button. When the button is clicked, you load all 100 images at the same time (Promise.all) and console.log the time it takes.

5.b) [for await + fetch] Redo 5.a, but this time load the images one at a time with a for await cycle, and console.log the total time it takes.

pages.name: Exercises
pages.content:
Exercises:

1. (http server) Take one more look at the web server we discussed in the lecture (BMI app). In particular, inspect the code to understand what happens in the server every time it receive a http request until the resulting response is sent.


2. (fetch, POST, routing) Make a spy site that receives information on what you are interested into. The spy site (web server you develop) provides the web page.

  a. (client side) The web page has some buttons and images. Any time your mouse hovers over an element on the page, this is caught by a "onmouseover" event-handler, and the web page performs a POST (using the fetch() method) to an endpoint in the server.

  b. (server side) The HTTP server has endpoints to serve HTML web pages, and one endpoint to receive the POST requests from the "onmouseover" event handler. The HTTP server will route the request to a function that receives the POST data and performs a console.log of the received data.


3. (file handling) Change the HTTP server from point 2 to append the data received by "onmouseover" event handler to a local file. Consider which data must be received to uniquely identify which computer the data was received from (address of the client? port?). After using the system for a couple of minutes, open the local file and see the data that was logged.


4. (cookies) Create one more endpoint on the HTTP server. From this endpoint, serve a HTML page that uses Javascript to manage a cookie. The key-value pair ("visit", "") on the cookie is used to count how many times the user visits the page. Every time the page is loaded, the Javascript on the client will access the cookie to print on the web pages "you visited the page --- times", and add 1 to the key "visit" of the cookie. After trying this out a few times, delete the cookie from the "Privacy and Security" panel of the "Settings", and revisit the page, to see that it appears to be the first time you visit it.

pages.name: Exercises
pages.content:
The code examples are very "spaghetti". Exercises 1 and 2 aim at producing a well-engineered code, starting probably from the BMI App.


    1. Create a quiz application using Server-Sent Events. Base your code on the SSE chat code and on the BMI calculator from Lecture 4. Hints:
            • The server serves what is inside the PublicResources folder (e.g.: an HTML file, a CSS file, a JS file) similarly to the BMI calculator.
            • The server allows the clients to connect and provide a username.
            • The server reads from a local file a list of questions and potential answers. Every minute, it pushes one of them to the connected clients (SSE, event type: question). When the server receives an answer, it compares to the correct answer for the current question and, if correct, it adds one point to the related username, and pushes the new score tables to the clients (SSE, event type: scoretable)
            • The HTML page has 4 areas (DIVs?), one to show the questions, one to allow the user to input an answer to be sent to the server, one to show the scoretable, and a clock.
            • On the client side, they allow to input a username, and use an EventSource to connect to the server.
            • The client allows the user to input an answer to be sent to the server using fetch() with a option object to specify the use of the POST method.
            • Every time the client receives a scoretable, it shows it in the correct DIV.
            • Every time the client receives a question from the server, it shows it in the correct DIV, and resets the clock in the clock's DIV to show how much time the client has to send an answer. 
    2. Implement the quiz application using websockets. The requirements are the same of the SSE-based quiz application, but it must be done using websockets.
    3. Design an API for in YAML for financial accounting, generate the code, and implement the business logic. Hints: for implement some logic on the services, and then use Postman (or curl) to experiment with it.
      1. Copy the contents of slide 42 (beware of indenting, use this file instead) and paste that into editor.swagger.io
      2. Customize it: add endpoints to add create/delete an account (methods: POST and DELETE), add/remove money from an account (methods: PUT and PUT), see how much money an account has (method: GET)
      3. Generate a server skeleton (type node.js).
      4. Unzip the file, and execute "npm install" in the unzipped folder. Open the index.js in visual studio.
      5. Fill up the business logic for the 5 endpoints
      6. Write postman requests to try out the 5 endpoints
      7. Monitor the interactions using Wireshark

  3. Mulig eksamensopgave:







  4. P25
  5. P31

  6. Et streaming firma skal have uploadet et ny datasæt på 40 terabytes til en server, der er placeret tæt hos forbrugerne, men et stykke væk fra firmaet. Deres Internet forbindelse til serveren tillader en gennemsnitlig upload hastighed på 100 Mbps.   Hvor lang tid tager det? Sammenlig tid og pris med at sende en fysisk pakke med et speditionsfirma med næste-dags levering. Antag firmaet køber en dedikeret forbindelse til serveren, med 10 gange højere kapacitet. Hvor lang tid tager det så? Hvad bliver den gennemsnitlige udnyttelsesgrad af denne, under antagelse af at et nyt datasæt uploades en gang om måneden, og den daglige trafik (email, web-surfing, etc) udgør 20 Mbps i gennemsnit. Overvej de praktiske konsekvenser i scenariet.

modules.name: You will find the study café in room 0.2.12 at Sel...
modules.description:
You will find the study café in room 0.2.12 at Selma Lagerlöfs Vej 300, 9220 Aalborg Ø. It is open every Wednesday from 15-17.

In the study café, you can work on your assignments in a quiet environment, where it is ok to ask for help from the other students who are present - regardless of the degree they are on.

Some show up and have concrete mathematical challenges, others need help to understand a task and others might show up to get some sparring on an idea for a solution 😊

You will also be able to ask for help from the three students who run the Study Café. They are not experts in everything, but they are all doing a master's degree and can definitely help you get ahead in one way or another.

There is free coffee 😊

Feel free to sign up for the FB group, where you can ask small questions and where you can follow along to see if anything special is happening

contents.name: Status Seminar
contents.summary:
Each group must participate in a status seminar as part of their project work. Soon after group formation, each group will be assigned to an 'opponent group'. The organization of the status seminar goes as follows:

Before the Status Seminar:

  • Prepare a short report (max 10 pages) summarising the following info:
    • Problem description [description of the problem and its motivation]
    • Preliminary Problem Analysis [summary of the analysis]
    • Description of group organization and workflow [brief description of the working plan, and workflow, including risk assessment]
  • Submit the report mentioned above to your group opponent (cc to your supervisor and PBL consultant)
  • Read the report you received from the other group and take note of relevant feedback
  • Prepare a 25 min presentation (with slides) summarising the report

Agenda of the Status Seminar (for each group)
  • 25 min presentation of Group
  • 20 min feedback from Opponent Group
  • 15 min break, then the next group follows

See the plan for the status seminar below. Remember that you have to attend also as an opponent group.

Group supervisors will attend the status seminar and moderate the discussion. Remember to give useful and constructive feedback and be open to suggestions on improving your work. 

Important Dates:

  • Deadline to submit the report to the opponent group: 11 March (12:00) 
  • Period of the status Seminar: 18-27 March (soon we will post here the plan with exact dates for each group)

pages.content:
SEMESTER DESCRIPTION

Semester details

2. semester on the bachelor in Computer Science (DAT2) - Link to Study Curriculum: https://studieordninger.aau.dk/2023/38/3921
2. semester on the bachelor in Software (AAL-SW2) - Link to Study Curriculum: https://studieordninger.aau.dk/2023/38/3925
Semester framework theme A Larger Program Developed by a Group/Et større program udviklet af en gruppe
PBL Workshop

Semester organization and time schedule Three courses, together with a project are offered this semester
The courses are normal 5 ECTS courses with individual examinations
The semester project is documented in the form of a project report and the examination form is a group examination.

Time Schedule (modifications may occur)
Semester coordinator and study secretary
Giovanni Bacci (giovbacci@cs.aau.dk) and Sidsel Overgaard (sgmo@cs.aau.dk)


MODULE DESCRIPTION

Module title (ENG/DK) and ECTS credits A Larger Program Developed by a Group /Et større program udviklet af en gruppe, 15 ECTS
Module description Link: https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/DNSDATFB220?lang=da-DK 
Module supervisors Link: Supervisors & Project Proposals
Type and language Project and in English
Objectives

The student learns how to formulate a problem as a computational problem and to use programming languages and algorithmic design to solve it. The aim is also to gain additional experience in problem-oriented project work in a group in a natural progression from 1st  Semester. 
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters  
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 450 hours.
Module activities (course sessions etc.)
Rules for project work with an external company It can be found here: https://www.cs.aau.dk/education/rules-forms
Examination Oral examination based on a project

Module title (DK/ENG) and ECTS credits 
Algorithms and Data Structures /Algoritmer og datastrukturer (ALG), 5 ECTS
Module description Link: https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/DSNDATFB211?lang=da-DK
Module coordinator Giovanni Bacci (giovbacci@cs.aau.dk)
Type and language Course and in English
Objectives This course has the aim to teach the main principles of algorithm design. Through a number of examples, the course will try to convey both the general spirit of thinking about the algorithms and a number of commonly used techniques for algorithm design. We will see how these techniques can be used to solve different problems. The important part of the course will deal with the analysis of algorithms, where we will look at the ways to reason about the efficiency and correctness of algorithms. Finally, the course will present a small toolbox of commonly used algorithms and data structures. These algorithms can be considered to be the "classics" of computer science. In the course, we will spend plenty of time with each of these algorithms, favoring the quality of understanding to the quantity of algorithms covered
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 150 hours
Participants DAT2, AAL-SW2, DVML2
Prerequisites for participation
  • Understanding of basic control structures of imperative programming languages (i.e., if-then-else, for loop, while loop, variable assignment)
  • knowledge of basic arithmetic and properties of functions such as logarithms, polynomials, max, min, etc.
  • understanding of basic proof principles. In particular, induction.
Module activities (course sessions etc.) The course consists of 12 lectures followed by exercise sessions + 2 exam simulations 
Examination Written or oral examination - Please note: FINAL examination form (and aid if any) will be posted on the course page  

Module title (ENG/DK) and ECTS credits   
Internetworking and Web-programming / Internetværk og web-programmering (IWP), 5 ECTS
Module description Link: https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/DSNDATFB212?lang=da-DK
Module coordinator Michele Albano (mialb@cs.aau.dk), Brian Nielsen (bnielsen@cs.aau.dk)
Type and language Course and in English/Dansk
Objectives This course has the aim to give an understand how applications communicate over the the Internet, how the Internet is structured, understand the workings of common Internet Protocols (in particular TCP and UDP), security challenges, and give basic skills in developing web-based applications. 
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters The course is related to the programming course at 1st semester, programming courses at later semesters, computer architecture & operating systems (4th semester), distributed systems (7th semester), and IoT (for BAIT)
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 150 hours
Participants DAT2, AAL-SW2, BaIT6T
Preprequisites for participation Programming experience from 1st semester.
Module activities (course sessions etc.) The course consists of lecture/exercise sessions
Examination Written or oral examination - Please note: FINAL examination form and aids (if any) will be posted on the course page

Module title (ENG/DK) and ECTS credits 
Probability Theory and Linear Algebra /Sandsynlighedsteori og lineær algebra (SLIAL) 5 ECTS
Module description Link:https://moduler.aau.dk/course/2023-2024/22BMATSLIAL?lang=da-DK
Module coordinator Anton Evgrafov anev@math.aau.dk
Type and language Course, in English and Danish
Objectives The objective of this course is to expose the students to the fundamental linear algebraic and probabilistic/combinatorial concepts, such as:
  • Matrix and vector operations
  • Linear transformations and their connection to matrices
  • Invertible matrices/linear transformations, solution of linear algebraic systems
  • Orthogonality and least squares problems
  • Linear optimization
  • Discrete probability spaces and combinatorics
  • Markov chains, stationary distributions, and connections to linear algebra
Academic content and conjunction with other modules/semesters See above
Scope and expected performance It should be stressed that AAU expects each student to spend 30 hours of study per ECTS credit, amounting to 150 hours
Participants AAL-SW2, DAT2
Preprequisites for participation
Module activities (course sessions etc.) The course consists of four blocks.  Each block begins with a lecture followed by an exercise session.  Most other sessions in each block are "self-studies with help", where the students study the material independently (video lecture, textbook) while the teachers/assistants are available for help/answering questions.  Each block also contains a non-scheduled "self-study without help", where the students study the course material (video lecture, textbook, exercises) on their own.  Each block is concluded with a workshop/"mini-project".  
Examination Written or oral examination - Please note: FINAL examination form and aids (if any) will be posted on the course page
Examinatio, Spring 2024 Oral examination, 15 min/student including the grading.  The short presentation of a randomly selected workshop forms the basis for the final oral exam (~5 min).  The presentation is followed up by additional questions within the course's syllabus (~5 min). You may prepare ~5 slides/workshop and either print them out or show the screen when you present at the exam.

pages.name: Plan for exams in June and re-exams in August 2024
pages.intro: Should you need to apply for re-exam, do so by email to eksamenstilmelding_cs@cs.aau.dk. Remember to use your AAU mail. The email must include your name, study programme and semester for the re-exam (for instance SW2), month of the re-exam (August 2024 or June 2025), and which re-exams you wish to enroll for. You can enroll for more re-exams in the same email, as long as it is for the same semester.
pages.content:
Exam summer 2024
Timetable for exams on DAT2/SW2

The examination timetables with a link to information on date and time is available in the table below. If you have any questions, please contact your study secretary (Sidsel Overgaard, sgmo@cs.aau.dk)

Date Examination
07.06.24 at 10.00-14.00 Internetværk og web-programmering (IWP)
14.06.24 at 10.00-14.00 Algoritmer og datastrukturer (ALG)
20.06.24 - 27.06.24 + buffer on 28.06.24 Sandsynlighedsteori og lineær algebra (SLIAL)
20.06.24 - 27.06.24 Project exam

NOTE!!! Students are personally responsible for checking which exams they are signed up for. So please check the lists thoroughly and inform your study secretary if anything needs to be altered! PLEASE do this in due time before the exams!

AAUCard
Always remember to bring your AAUcard when attending an exam!

Handing in the project in Digital Exam
Remember to hand in your project no later than 29.05.24 by 12.00 in Digital Exam (Danish: Digital Eksamen).
Rules for submitting project documentation (Danish: aflevering og upload af projektdokumentation).
See information about the "definition of external collaboration on student projects".

Title of your project:
It is very important that you enter the title of your project correctly when submitting it in Digital Exam. In the field ’Title', please write only the title of your project. Do not write project number, semester or similar in this field. The title you enter in Digital Exam will appear on your final diploma.

Digital Exam and Solemn Declaration (Tro- og Loveerklæring)
Digital Exam is ready one week before the deadline of the submission of the project (report).
Solemn Declaration is mandatory for all project (report) submissions in Digital Exam. Deadline for reply of the solemn declaration is the same time as upload of the project (report).
If you are in a group: one student is to upload the report on behalf of the whole group and afterwards invite the other members to the group. Only the student who uploads the report will be able to see the solemn declaration in Digital Exam.
Important!!! When you accept an invitation to a group in Digital Exam, at the same time, you will also be accepting the uploaded report and the solemn declaration.

Arrive in plenty of time before your examination
Make sure to arrive at least 30 minutes before your examination begins. 

Withdrawal from the examination and info. about signing up for re-exam
Please note: you are automatically enrolled for your first examination attempt on 1st and 2nd semester.

  • You CANNOT withdraw from the first examination attempt in January/June.
  • If you do not pass the ordinary exam in January/June (1st attempt) you will NOT automatically be signed up for the re-exam in February/August. You are responsible for registering for the second (and third) examination attempt yourself. This should be done by email to eksamenstilmelding_cs@cs.aau.dk no later than 12.00 (noon) five working days before the re-exam takes place - but you are strongly recommended to sign up shortly after the result is known, so you don’t forget it! Please include the name of the exam(s) you wish to enroll for as well as the name of your study programme and semester.
  • If you do not pass the 3rd attempt, please note that you have to apply for a dispensation shortly after the exam!!

First-year examinations
Students in their first year of a bachelor programme must participate in at least one examination in each module on the 1st and 2nd semester before the end of their first year of study (first-year examinations).
See more in chapter 11 of “RULES FOR COURSE AND EXAM REGISTRATION AT AALBORG UNIVERSITY”.

Special conditions for exams
If you have a physical or mental functional impairment, you can apply for special conditions for exams, e.g. 25% extra time for written exams or the right to use different forms of supporting tools (from the SPS-office). Please see chapter 3.4 in examination policies and procedures about special conditions.
Applications must be sent to the study board by sending an email to cs-sn@cs.aau.dk no later than 6 weeks before the exam. You should include information about your specific needs and for which exams. Remember to include documentation for your special condition.

Illness
Should you be ill on the day of the exam or during the exam, please note that you have to contact and have a consultation with your doctor (earlier, or at least on the same day as the exam takes place) and hand in a medical certificate (with the date of the exam) to your study secretary, no later than 2 weeks after the date of the exam. You will receive information on whether the medical certificate is approved or not from your study secretary.

Equipment in the examination room
It is the group's/student's own responsibility to make sure that the necessary (computer) equipment is available in the examination room(s). As a standard, a projector or a TV-screen is available in the examination room(s). Please contact Aage Sørensen in room 0.1.22 or by e-mail aage@cs.aau.dk if you have any special requests in addition to the equipment already available. Remember to make your arrangements in plenty of time before the examination.

Examination rules in general
Please find information about the examination rules in general on the website for the Study Board of Computer Science.
View information about the 7-point grading scale (Danish version). And English version.

Did you know that the vast majority of students comply with exam rules – are you one of them? And do you know the consequences of exam cheating? And what does it really mean to cheat at the exam?
If you participate in or perform exam cheating yourself, you will be expelled from the exam. This means a wasted exam attempt. In case of severe exam cheating or repeated cheating, you run the risk of being expelled from the university, which means that you will be delayed in your education and you risk having to repay SU. If you cheat or help others through exams, you contribute to give a false picture of your own or your fellow students' exam performances. This will damage the reputation of AAU, your own reputation, and your fellow students' reputation.
